revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = Judah Friedlander.jpg | caption = Friedlander at The Stand in June 2016. | image_size = 230px | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|3|16}} | birth_place = [[Gaithersburg, Maryland]], U.S. | residence = [[Queens, New York]], U.S. | name = Judah Friedlander | occupation = Actor, comedian | yearsactive = 1989–present | website = {{URL|http://www.judahfriedlander.com}} }}
'''Judah Friedlander''' (born March 16, 1969)<ref name=NYTBIO>{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/292135/Judah-Friedlander/biography |title=Judah Friedlander biography |author=Andrea LeVasseur |work=All Movie Guide |publisher=All Media Guide |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=IMDB>{{IMDb name |id=0295103 |name=Judah Friedlander}}</ref> is an American actor and comedian, known for playing the role of writer [[Frank Rossitano]] on the [[NBC]] [[sitcom]] ''[[30 Rock]]''.<ref name=NYT1>{{cite news |title=Working a Crowd Is Part of the Act |first=Jason |last=Zinoman |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/06/arts/television/judah-friedlanders-stand-up-comedy.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 5, 2012 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=GOTHAMIST>{{cite web |url=http://gothamist.com/2011/06/08/judah_friedlander_talks.php |title=Judah Friedlander Talks 30 Rock, Standup and Ping Pong |last=Feldmar |first=Jamie |date=June 8, 2011 |work=Gothamist |publisher=Gothamist LLC |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130529081612/http://gothamist.com/2011/06/08/judah_friedlander_talks.php |archivedate=May 29, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name=IFC>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2009/07/judah-friedlander |title=Judah Friedlander Keeps Truckin’ |author=Aaron Hillis |date=July 1, 2009 |work=IFC |publisher=AMC Networks |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> Friedlander is also known for his role as [[Toby Radloff]] in the film ''[[American Splendor (film)|American Splendor]]'',<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=GOTHAMIST/><ref name=NYT2>{{cite news |title=A Night Out With: Judah Friedlander; The Hug Guy Takes the Stage |first=Dave |last=Hill |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D07E7DA1138F930A15752C0A9639C8B63 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 23, 2005 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> a role that garnered him favorable reviews and a nomination for best supporting actor at the 2004 [[Independent Spirit Awards]].<ref name=NYT2/><ref>{{cite news |title=American Splendor (2003). Full Review; A Comics Guy, Outside the Box |first=Elvis |last=Elvis Mitchell |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9903E1D71630F936A2575BC0A9659C8B63 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 15, 2003 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=NBCBIO>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/30-rock/about/bio/cast/judah-friedlander/585379 |title=Bios: Judah Friedlander |work=nbc.com |publisher=NBCUniversal Media |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=BOSTON>{{cite news |title=A world-class loser in films, Friedlander is a champ onstage |first=Nick A. |last=Zaino III |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/events/articles/2005/11/11/a_world_class_loser_in_films_friedlander_is_a_champ_onstage/ |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=November 11, 2005 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=PLAIN>{{cite news |title=Judah Friedlander takes his talents to Hilarities |first=Michael K. |last=McIntyre |url=http://www.cleveland.com/dining/index.ssf/2011/06/judah_friedlander_takes_his_ta.html |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=HOLLYREP>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/30-rock-nbc-judah-friedlander-facts-280892 |title='30 Rock's' Judah Friedlander: 5 Things You Didn't Know About Me |author=Jethro Nededog |date=January 12, 2012 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> Earlier in his career he was recognized as "the hug guy" from the music video for the 2001 [[Dave Matthews Band]] single "[[Everyday (Dave Matthews Band song)|Everyday]]".<ref name=IFC/><ref name=NYT2/><ref name=TRIBLIVE>{{cite news |title='30 Rock' star Judah Friedlander takes comedy on road |first=Loeffler |last=William |url=http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/more/s_503377.html#axzz28LvZ3Ky2 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review |date=April 19, 2007 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref>
Friedlander is known for his distinctive look, which includes oversized glasses, shaggy hair, a T-shirt and [[trucker hat]] (both often emblazoned with slogans such as "world champion"), and a generally unkempt appearance.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=NYT1/><ref name=PLAIN/><ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=TRIBLIVE/><ref name=PUNCH>{{cite web |url=http://www.laughspin.com/2005/11/07/judah-friedlander/ |title=Judah Friedlander: The World Champion Speaks |author=Tasha A. Harris |date=November 7, 2005 |work=Punchline Magazine |publisher=Laughspin |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616073351/http://www.laughspin.com/2005/11/07/judah-friedlander/ |archivedate=June 16, 2012 |df= }}</ref> It is a look he maintains as a stand-up comedian, during most of his public appearances, and which he has employed in some of his acting roles.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=NYT1/><ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=THEGRID>{{cite news |title=What do you say, Judah Friedlander? |first=Chris |last=Berube |url=http://www.thegridto.com/culture/television/what-do-you-say-judah-friedlander/ |newspaper=The Grid |date=May 11, 2011 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref>
==Early life== Friedlander was born in [[Gaithersburg, Maryland]], the son of Shirley and Art Friedlander.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=TRIBLIVE/> His father was of Russian [[Jew]]ish descent and his mother, a native of [[Pittsburgh]], is [[Croatian American]].<ref name=TRIBLIVE/><ref name=NYMAG>{{cite news |title=Judah Friedlander Thinks Manhattan Pizza Has ‘Gone Downhill’ |first=Alexandra |last=Vallis |url=http://newyork.grubstreet.com/2009/05/friedlander.html |newspaper=New York Magazine |date=May 22, 2009 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2517 |title=The next generation of Jewish Humor in America |date=October 2007 |work=City Pages |accessdate=February 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127101040/http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2517 |archivedate=January 27, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
As a child, Friedlander drew political cartoons and made animated films.<ref name=ANNARBOR>{{cite web |url=http://www.annarbor.com/entertainment/30-rocks-judah-friedlander-offers-his-world-champion-stand-up-on-thursday/ |title=30 Rock's Judah Friedlander offering his World Champion stand-up in Ann Arbor |author=Jenn McKee |date=April 9, 2012 |work=AnnArbor.com |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> He first tried stand-up comedy in 1989 at the age of 19 while attending [[New York University]].<ref name=NYT1/><ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=PUNCH/><ref name=PHILLY>{{cite news |title=Judah Friedlander Likes Hats |first=Joel |last=Mathis |url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/screen/tv/Judah-Friedlander-Likes-Hats-42379727.html |newspaper=Philadelphia Weekly |date=April 3, 2009 |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411151627/http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/screen/tv/Judah-Friedlander-Likes-Hats-42379727.html |archivedate=April 11, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Career== [[File:10.12.12JudahFriedlanderByLuigiNovi1.jpg|thumb|left|Friedlander at the [[CollegeHumor]] presentation at the 2012 [[New York Comic Con]]]]
===Stand-up comedy=== Friedlander has performed stand-up comedy regularly throughout his entertainment career.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name=GOTHAMIST/><ref name=PUNCH/> He continued to perform stand-up several nights a week in [[New York City]] while working on the sitcom ''30 Rock''.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name=GOTHAMIST/> Friedlander has stated that he is most relaxed when doing stand-up<ref name=HOLLYREP/> and that he considers stand-up to be his first true love,<ref name=TORSTAR>{{cite news |title=Judah Friedlander: Hats off to standup guy |first=Raju |last=Mudhar |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/article/502734--judah-friedlander-hats-off-to-standup-guy |newspaper=Toronto Star |date=September 21, 2008 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> preferring it to acting.<ref name=VULTURE>{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2010/09/30_rocks_judah_friedlander.html |title=30 Rock’s Judah Friedlander on Karate and the Hat That Was Too Hot for NBC |author=Alexandra Martell |date=September 23, 2010 |work=Vulture |publisher=New York Magazine |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> He stated in 2012 that stand-up comedy is "still the most important thing I do from an artistic standpoint."<ref name=CITYPAGES>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.citypages.com/dressingroom/2012/04/judah_friedlander_world_champion_standup.php |title=Judah Friedlander on comedy, ladies, and karate |author=Patrick Strait |date=April 9, 2012 |work=City Pages |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918221026/http://blogs.citypages.com/dressingroom/2012/04/judah_friedlander_world_champion_standup.php |archivedate=September 18, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Friedlander has cited comedians [[Steven Wright]], [[Sam Kinison]] and [[John Mulrooney]] as influences.<ref name=KANSAS>{{cite news |title=After ‘30 Rock,’ comic Judah Friedlander is ready for new projects |first=Timothy |last=Finn |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2013/02/06/4050785/judah-friedlander-steps-off-the.html#storylink=cpy |newspaper=The Kansas City Star |date=February 6, 2013 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> He also says that [[Dave Attell]] is one of his favorite comics.<ref name=KANSAS/>
Friedlander's comedic performances often feature him making outrageous and bombastic claims about himself with a deadpan delivery.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name=NYT2/><ref name=TRIBLIVE/><ref name=TORSTAR/> Many of these claims are reflected in slogans displayed on the many [[trucker hats]] he wears — the most common being "World Champion", a slogan he has worn in various languages.<ref name=NYT2/><ref name=PLAIN/><ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=NYMAG/><ref name=ANNARBOR/>
One of his claims include being an expert in karate, having achieved an "extra-dark [[Black belt (martial arts)|black belt]]" in the sport.<ref name=GOTHAMIST/><ref name=THEGRID/><ref name=WASHTIMES>{{cite news |title=Get Out: Judah Friedlander |first=Mike |last=Riggs |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/nov/24/get-out-judah-friedlander/ |newspaper=The Washington Times |date=November 24, 2011 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> In 2010, he authored the humor book ''How to Beat Up Anybody: An Instructional and Inspirational Karate Book by the World Champion''.<ref name=NBCBIO/><ref name=ANNARBOR/> Friedlander's claims provide comedic irony when contrasted against his nonchalant attitude and physical appearance.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name=PLAIN/> Friedlander wears large, thick-rimmed glasses, is often unshaven and is generally unkempt.<ref name=NYT1/><ref name=IFC/><ref name=ANNARBOR/> His physique has also been described as "doughy".<ref name=PLAIN/><ref name=TRIBLIVE/>
The look that Friedlander employs during his stand-up has also carried over into some of his television and film roles, including his ''30 Rock'' role as TV writer [[Frank Rossitano]].<ref name=THEGRID/><ref name=ANNARBOR/> Frank is however much lazier than Friedlander's "World Champion" persona.<ref name=THEGRID/><ref name=TIMEOUT>{{cite web |url=http://www.timeoutchicago.com/arts-culture/comedy/15255886/judah-friedlander-at-mayne-stage-comedy-review |title=Judah Friedlander at Mayne Stage |author=Jenna Marotta |date=April 12, 2012 |work=Time Out Chicago |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref>
In 2007, ''[[Heeb]]'' magazine included Friedlander in their list of "100 people you need to know about".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2517 |title=The next generation of Jewish Humor in America |date=October 2007 |work=All About Jewish Theatre |accessdate=February 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127101040/http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2517 |archivedate=January 27, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===Television=== [[File:10.9.10JudahFriedlanderByLuigiNovi.jpg|thumb|left|Friedlander in October 2010]]Friedlander played the role of a [[techie]] on the [[Al Franken]] sitcom ''[[LateLine]]'' in 1999.<ref name=IMDB/> Over the 2000s Friedlander held guest roles on several television shows, including ''[[Spin City]]'', ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]'' and ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]'', as well as providing voices for characters on the animated series ''[[Wonder Showzen]]'' and ''[[Xavier: Renegade Angel]]''.<ref name=IMDB/> Friedlander made regular appearances on the entertainment and pop-culture program ''[[Best Week Ever]]''.<ref name="BOSTON"/><ref name=TORSTAR/> He appeared as the online co-host of the 2009 [[TV Land Awards]], alongside main stage host [[Neil Patrick Harris]].<ref>{{cite news |title=What's On Today |first=Kathryn |last=Shattuck |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9401E3D81E3FF935A15757C0A96F9C8B63 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 26, 2009 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upnorthlive.com/entertainment/story.aspx?id=289095 |title=Christina Applegate Picks Up TV Land Innovator Award |author=GossipGirls.com |date=April 20, 2009 |work=UpNorthLive.com |publisher=Barrington Broadcasting Group |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130412042901/http://www.upnorthlive.com/entertainment/story.aspx?id=289095 |archivedate=April 12, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Judah Friedlander at the 67th Annual Peabody Awards for 30 Rock.jpg|thumb|Judah Friedlander at the 67th Annual [[Peabody Awards]] for ''[[30 Rock]]'']] Friedlander was a regular cast member of the sitcom ''[[30 Rock]]'' throughout its entire run, from October 11, 2006, to January 31, 2013.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=KANSAS/> His character, [[Frank Rossitano]], is a sarcastic and wisecracking writer on the fictional show ''TGS with Tracy Jordan''<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=POSTGAZ>{{cite news |title='30 Rock' star rockets into Pittsburgh Thursday, April 19, 2007 |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/ae/tuned-in/30-rock-star-rockets-into-pittsburgh-481584/ |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=April 13, 2007 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> Frank is lazy, slovenly, and lives with his mother (played by [[Patti Lupone]]).<ref name=ANNARBOR/><ref name=NATIONAL>{{cite news |title=Judah Friedlander, comic crusader |first=Barry |last=Hertz |url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2010/11/22/judah-friedlander-comic-crusader/ |newspaper=National Post |date=November 22, 2010 |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411115428/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2010/11/22/judah-friedlander-comic-crusader/ |archivedate=April 11, 2013 |df= }}</ref> He is also sex-obsessed, which he often reveals by way of vulgar and sexually suggestive comments.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=ANNARBOR/><ref name=POSTGAZ/> Friedlander has stated that Frank Rossitano is based on at least two writers with whom [[Tina Fey]] used to work at ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref name=POSTGAZ/> His ever-changing, slogan-bearing trucker hats also became a running gag on the show.<ref name=VULTURE/><ref name=POSTGAZ/> Friedlander makes his hats himself and created enough of them to be able to wear a different one in each scene of ''30 Rock'', which is about three hats per show.<ref name=TRIBLIVE/><ref name=PHILLY/><ref name=POSTGAZ/>
Friedlander has appeared on [[late-night talk show]]s such as ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'', ''[[The Daily Show with Trevor Noah]]'',''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'', ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' and ''[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]''.<ref name=IMDB/> In 2010 Friedlander appeared in 2 episodes of the children's series ''[[Sesame Street]]''.<ref name=IMDB/><ref name=NBCBIO/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.laughspin.com/2010/02/18/judah-friedlander-is-spectacular-on-sesame-street/ |title=Judah Friedlander is 'spectacular' on Sesame Street |author=Dylan P. Gadino |date=February 18, 2010 |work=Laughspin Magazine |publisher=Laughspin |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627111302/http://www.laughspin.com/2010/02/18/judah-friedlander-is-spectacular-on-sesame-street |archivedate=June 27, 2013 |df= }}</ref> He also appeared as a panelist on ''[[The Burn with Jeff Ross]]'' in 2013.<ref name=IMDB/>
In May and June 2014, Friedlander narrated [[ESPN]]'s ''Inside: U.S. Soccer’s March to Brazil'' six-part series in preparation for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] in Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/05/12/16/55/140512-espn-inside-us-soccer-series-premier |title=New ESPN Series ‘Inside: U.S. Soccer’s March to Brazil’ Premieres Tuesday |publisher=US Soccer |date=12 May 2014 |accessdate=11 June 2014 }}</ref>
He has appeared on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[The Last Word with Lawrence O'Donnell|Last Word With Lawrence O'Donnell]]'' and provided personal commentary on [[FIFA World Cup|The World Cup]] and [[soccer]] in general.<ref>{{cite news |title='The Last Word with Lawrence O'Donnell' for Tuesday, July 1st, 2014|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/55561503/ns/msnbc/t/last-word-lawrence-odonnell-tuesday-july-st/#.VC695hYzJhs|date=July 1, 2014 }}</ref>
===Film and video=== In 2001, Friedlander played "the hug guy" in the [[music video]] for the [[Dave Matthews Band]] single "[[Everyday (Dave Matthews Band song)|Everyday]]"; his character is seen hugging various people throughout the video.<ref name=NYT2/><ref name=TRIBLIVE/><ref name=PUNCH/> Friedlander was recognized for his "hug guy" role for years after appearing in the video, causing complete strangers to offer him hugs.<ref name=NYT2/> The same year, he appeared in the comedy film ''[[Wet Hot American Summer]]''.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=IMDB/>
In 2003 Friedlander played [[Toby Radloff]] in the [[biopic]] ''[[American Splendor (film)|American Splendor]]'', a role that received favorable reviews — his performance was deemed "unforgettable"<ref name=NYTBIO/> by ''[[The New York Times]]'' and "pitch-perfect" by both Nick A. Zaino III of ''[[The Boston Globe]]''<ref name=BOSTON/> and Dan Dinicola of ''[[The Daily Gazette]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title='American Splendor' as delightful as oddball subject Pekar |first=Dan |last=Dinicola |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fN8qAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UIgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2396,2602290&dq=judah-friedlander+american-splendor&hl=en |date=September 12, 2003 |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> He was also nominated in the category of best supporting actor at the 2004 [[Independent Spirit Awards]].<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=NYT2/><ref name=POSTGAZ/>
Friedlander had roles in the [[Ben Stiller]] films ''[[Meet the Parents]]'', ''[[Zoolander]]'' and ''[[Along Came Polly]]''.<ref name=NYTBIO/><ref name=IMDB/>
He had a starring role in the 2005 independent comedy ''[[Full Grown Men]]'' and a supporting role in the 2008 drama ''[[The Wrestler (2008 film)|The Wrestler]]''.<ref name=IMDB/><ref name=NBCBIO/><ref name=THEGRID/>
He has also appeared in films such as ''[[Duane Hopwood]]'', ''[[Chapter 27]]'', ''[[Southern Belles]]'', ''[[Live Free or Die (2006 film)|Live Free or Die]]'', and ''[[Feast (2005 film)|Feast]]''.<ref name=IMDB/><ref name=NBCBIO/>
==Personal life== Friedlander has lived in the [[New York City]] area over most of his career, with the exception of two years in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=GOTHAMIST/> Currently residing in [[Queens]],<ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=CITYPAGES/> he has stated that he prefers living in New York.<ref name=GOTHAMIST/>
Friedlander enjoys playing [[ping-pong]].<ref name=GOTHAMIST/><ref name=IFC/><ref name=HOLLYREP/><ref name=NYMAG/> As a child he had played the sport competitively, and he took it up again in 2008.<ref name=GOTHAMIST/><ref name=IFC/> He is a big fan of [[professional wrestling]], which is often used as subject matter for his trademark hats and shirts. He is also a fan of the [[New York Red Bulls]], he has attended games at [[Red Bull Arena (New Jersey)|Red Bull Arena]], and has appeared in commercials for the team.<ref name="Major League Soccer">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lWMOp9r0kPY|title=Judah Friedlander at LA vs NY|website=YouTube|publisher=Major League Soccer}}</ref>

Superjocks!" |- | 2005 || ''[[Sunday Pants]]'' || || Voice<br/>Segment "History According to Noodle" |- | 2006 || ''[[Wonder Showzen]]'' || Crickey || 2 episodes |- | 2006–2013 || ''[[30 Rock]]'' || Frank Rossitano || 119 episodes |- | 2007 || ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]] || Isabella || Episode: "Sally" |- | 2009 || ''[[Xavier: Renegade Angel]]'' || Big Papa Dick / Slippy Villager || Voices<br/>2 episodes |- | 2010 || ''[[Sesame Street]] || Inspector 4 || Episode: "Inspected by 4" |- | 2010 || ''[[The Life & Times of Tim]]'' || Ping Pong Guy || Voice<br/>Episode: "Stu Is Good at Something" |- | 2011 || ''[[The Heart, She Holler]]'' || || Episode: "Dare to Holler" |- | 2011 || ''[[Ice Age: A Mammoth Christmas]]'' || Head Mini Sloth || Voice<br/>Television special |- | 2013 || ''[[Childrens Hospital]]'' || [[Al Yankovic]] || Episode: "Country Weekend" |- | 2014 || ''[[Sharknado 2: The Second One]]'' || Brian || Television film |- | 2015 || ''[[Fresh Off the Boat (TV series)|Fresh Off the Boat]]'' || Ray || Episode: "Very Superstitious" |- | 2015 || ''[[Wet Hot American Summer: First Day of Camp]]'' || Ron von Kleinenstein || 2 episodes |- | 2015 | ''[[The Jim Gaffigan Show]]'' | Himself | Episode: "My Friend the Priest" |- | 2016 || ''[[Bordertown (2016 TV series)|Bordertown]]'' || Sanford Buckwald || Voice<br/>13 episodes |- | 2016 || ''[[Albert (2016 film)|Albert]]'' || Gene || Voice<br/>Television film |- | 2017 | ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'' | Ferdie | Voice<br/>Episode: "Like Gene for Chocolate" |- |2017 |''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]'' |Gordy |2 episodes |- |2017 |''America is the Greatest Country in the United States'' |Himself |Stand-up special; also director and editor |}
